content: The Fair Adjustment and Income Revenue for Social Security Act, also known as the FAIR Social Security Act, repeals the cap on compensation subject to the Federal Insurance Contributions Act. The FAIR Social Security Act amends various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 related to wages, self-employment income, and conforming amendments. It removes the cap on compensation subject to the Federal Insurance Contributions Act. The FAIR Social Security Act removes the contribution and benefit base limitation in various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, allowing for payments of taxes without regard to this limitation. The FAIR Social Security Act removes contribution and benefit base limitations in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, affecting sections 3231(e)(2)(C) and 3511(b). The amendments apply to remuneration received after December 31, 2015. The FAIR Social Security Act removes contribution and benefit base limitations in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, affecting sections 3231(e)(2)(C) and 3511(b) for remuneration received after December 31, 2015. Additionally, there is a reallocation of payroll tax revenue. The FAIR Social Security Act removes contribution and benefit base limitations in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, affecting sections 3231(e)(2)(C) and 3511(b) for remuneration received after December 31, 2015. There is also a reallocation of 2016 Payroll Tax Revenue, adjusting percentages in the Social Security Act. The FAIR Social Security Act adjusts percentages for wages and self-employment income reported after specific dates. For wages, the percentages are 1.80% before 2033, 1.60% between 2032 and 2050, and 1.80% after 2049. For self-employment income, the percentages are 1.80% before 2033. The Bureau of Labor Statistics will publish the "Consumer Price Index for Elderly Consumers" monthly to show changes in spending habits of individuals aged 62 and older in the US.
